docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Provide a lightweight, near-real-time view of each device's provisioning status for Ops (device prep) and Sales (customer readiness). Tracker ingests structured log output from automation scripts and pairs it with manual notes to create a single source of truth.

docs.title: Data Model
docs.text:
Minimal fields per device: - device_id (IMEI or serial) - sku - assigned_customer (optional until order allocated) - stage (enum: intake, baseline, apps, workspace, qa, ready, blocked) - stage_detail (free text or predefined codes) - operator (who ran provisioning) - updated_at (UTC timestamp) - log_path (link to raw log file from provision.sh) - blockers (array of strings, empty when none) - qa_checks (struct: openclaw_status, telegram_test, audio_test, storage_pct)

Storage options: 1. CSV/JSON file in repo for prototyping (automation/tracker-state.json). 2. Lite DB (SQLite) for multi-user access. 3. Future: hosted Airtable/Notion view fed by script uploads.

docs.title: Ingestion Flow
docs.text:
1. provision.sh writes logs under automation/logs/<timestamp>-provision.log with machine-readable markers, e.g. JSON: {"event":"install","pkg":"com.termux",...}.
  2. Tracker ingestion script (automation/update-tracker.py, future) parses latest log for each device and updates tracker store.
  3. Manual actions (inspection, QA anomalies) recorded via CLI prompts or quick form writing into same store.

docs.title: Status Views
docs.text:
• Ops Dashboard: Table grouped by stage, sorted by updated_at. Shows operator + blockers for triage.
  • Sales Snapshot: Filter for stage=ready or assigned_customer=<name> for ship dates.
  • Audit History: Logs remain immutable; tracker stores last event references + log_path for deep dive.

docs.title: Reading Mechanisms
docs.text:
• prep-tracker.md describes schema; initial implementation could be tracker-cli status (a simple Python script) that prints human-readable table using the JSON data.
  • Secondary: auto-generate Markdown summary during provisioning run and drop into automation/report-<device>.md for asynchronous review.

docs.title: Dependencies / Blockers
docs.text:
• Need consistent device identifier capture at start of script.
  • Logging format must include JSON markers to allow reliable ingestion (current script only human-readable; TODO: add log_json() helper).
  • Decide on shared storage (git-tracked file vs. lightweight hosted DB).

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Extend provision.sh with DEVICE_ID variable (read via adb shell getprop ro.serialno).
  2. Define tracker-state.json schema + sample entry.
  3. Build update-tracker.py to parse logs and update statuses.
  4. Iterate with Ops/Sales to confirm fields and dashboard access (Notion/Airtable embed optional).

docs.text: Goal: Have the customer fully operational, confident in daily use, and aware of next steps by the end of the call.

  2. “Thanks for choosing the Concierge kit! Today we’ll connect Wi-Fi, drop in your API key, link Telegram/Signal, and send a first message.”

  3. Confirm preferred communication channel for support follow-ups.

  4. Hardware & Wi-Fi (5 min)

  8. OpenClaw Setup (12 min)

  10. Review permissions pop-ups; explain why each is needed in plain language.
  11. Guide API key entry:

    • Note success or troubleshoot errors immediately.

  12. Customize basic preferences (timezone, notification style, voice vs. text default).

  13. Messaging Link + Test (7 min)

  14. Decide which channel (Telegram, Signal, both) they’ll use first.
  15. Stay on the line while they log in and approve the OpenClaw bot.
  16. Prompt them to send the scripted first message: “Hey OpenClaw, can you summarize my day in 3 bullets?”

  17. Confirm the reply arrives. Screenshot placeholder: [Add screenshot of successful first reply].

  18. Wrap-Up (3 min)

  19. Recap what’s working: Wi-Fi ✅, API key ✅, messaging ✅, first message ✅.
  20. Highlight the quick-start insert and onboarding hub URL.
  21. Set expectations: “I’ll email you the recap + links in a few minutes. Reply there or DM @OpenClawSupport if anything pops up.”

Is my data secure? Yes. API keys live in encrypted storage on the device. Messaging happens only through the channels you authorize (Telegram, Signal). You can factory reset from the OpenClaw app anytime before shipping the phone back.

Before you start: Have your Wi-Fi password, preferred AI API key (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.), and Telegram/Signal login handy. Keep the included charger connected so the phone stays powered during setup.

docs.text:

  2. Swipe down twice → tap and hold the Wi-Fi tile.
  3. Select your network → enter the password → Connect.
  4. Wait for the “Connected” badge before moving on.

Tip: If you use a guest network, make sure it allows device-to-internet access without captive portals.

docs.title: Step 2 – Launch the OpenClaw Setup Wizard
docs.text:
1. Tap the OpenClaw Setup icon.
  2. Accept permissions for notifications, microphone, and storage.
  3. When prompted, confirm your timezone so scheduled tasks line up with you.

![Placeholder: Permissions screen]

docs.title: Step 3 – Add Your AI Provider
docs.text:
1. Choose OpenAI, Anthropic, or “Custom API”.
  2. Paste your API key (long string starting with sk- or similar).
  3. Tap Verify Key. If successful, you’ll see a green check.
  4. The wizard stores the key securely in encrypted storage on the device.

Troubleshooting: If you see “Invalid key,” double-check for trailing spaces or expired keys. Contact your AI provider dashboard if you need to regenerate one.

docs.title: Step 4 – Link Telegram or Signal (or both)
docs.text:
1. On the “Messaging Channels” screen, pick Telegram first.
  2. Tap Link Telegram → the Telegram app opens.
  3. Sign in using your phone number and code.
  4. Approve the OpenClaw bot when prompted. You’ll see a “Connected” badge.
  5. Repeat the process for Signal if you use it.

Privacy note: All messages route through your chosen app. OpenClaw never shares your contacts or chat history.

docs.title: Step 5 – Send Your First Message
docs.text:
1. Tap the First Message shortcut on the home screen.
  2. Type “Hey OpenClaw, what can you help me with this week?”
  3. You should receive a reply within a few seconds. The wizard logs this step as complete.
  4. Pin this conversation for easy access later.

docs.title: 3. Daily Use Cheatsheet
docs.text:

  • Share context: Paste links, documents, or short bullet lists before requesting an action.
  • Voice options: Hold the microphone icon in Telegram/Signal to send a quick voice memo; OpenClaw transcribes automatically.
  • Attachments: Photos/screenshots forward fine. Mention what you want done (e.g., “Summarize the attached notes”).

docs.text:

API key error Reopen OpenClaw Setup → Settings → API Keys → re-enter your key. Make sure billing is active with your AI provider. Telegram messages stuck at “Sending” Check Telegram’s status bar for “Connecting…”. Toggle Airplane mode on/off, or switch to Signal temporarily. Voice prompts fail Ensure microphone permission is enabled (Settings → Apps → OpenClaw → Permissions). Battery drains fast Reduce screen brightness, close unused apps, and keep the charger connected during heavy use.

docs.title: Golden Image Process Note (Motorola XT2513v)
docs.text: Last updated: 2026-02-23

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Maintain a reference configuration ("golden image") that can be flashed onto any unit to hit the ≤60 min prep target. The golden image must include OS patches, OpenClaw app stack, workspace templates, and launcher configuration.

docs.title: Versioning Convention
docs.text: GI-<YYYYMMDD>-<rev> (e.g., GI-20260223-a). - YYYYMMDD: date the image was finalized. - rev: increment alphabetically when multiple cuts occur in the same day. - Maintain changelog entries describing OS build number, OpenClaw version, and notable tweaks. - Store checksum manifest (sha256sum.txt) alongside each release in /ops/golden-image-store/.

docs.title: Build Procedure (Monthly or on major release)
docs.text:
1. Base Device Prep
  2. Start with factory-new device or sanitized return.
  3. Apply latest OTA updates.
  4. Enable developer options, USB debugging, stay awake.
  5. Install & Configure Stack
  6. Install OpenClaw stable APK + supporting apps (Termux, Telegram, Signal, Files, Authenticator) using batch script.
  7. Import workspace template (latest versions of AGENTS.md, SOUL.md, USER.md, README-QUICKSTART.md, HEARTBEAT.md).
  8. Set launcher layout, wallpapers, quick settings toggles, and notification presets.
  9. Hardening & Clean-up
  10. Disable bloatware, set battery optimization exceptions, lock screen instructions.
  11. Clear cache/data for apps used only for validation (e.g., Telegram test bot).
  12. Ensure storage free space ≥80%.
  13. Snapshot Creation
  14. Reboot into bootloader; run adb shell getprop ro.build.version.incremental to record OS build.
  15. Use adb shell su -c "/system/bin/dd if=/dev/block/bootdevice/by-name/userdata of=/sdcard/golden-userdata.img" (or OEM tool) to capture partitions.
  16. Pull images to workstation: adb pull /sdcard/golden-userdata.img etc.
  17. Generate checksum manifest.
  18. Packaging
  19. Place partition images + manifest + changelog into versioned folder.
  20. Update golden-image-manifest.json with: json { "version": "GI-20260223-a", "os_build": "T2TZ33.43-19", "openclaw_apk": "2.3.1", "workspace_commit": "abc1234", "checksum_file": "sha256sum.txt" }

Automation candidate: scripted capture + packaging via shell + fastboot to minimize manual commands.

docs.title: Validation Procedure (Per release)
docs.text:
1. Flash the new image onto two test devices using flash-golden.sh <version> <serial>.
  2. Boot and complete onboarding; ensure no setup wizard blockers.
  3. Run quick QA (Steps A–C from SOP) and log results tagged Golden Validation.
  4. Have Automation Engineer diff automation scripts to ensure compatibility; update install scripts with new version string.
  5. Once validated, mark current_version in manifest and notify Device Prep + Automation channels.

docs.title: Distribution & Storage
docs.text:
• Store master copies on encrypted drive + repo (LFS) with restricted access.
  • Provide SD card copies labeled with version + checksum.
  • Replace SD card contents immediately after a new release; archive old card separately.

docs.title: Rollback Procedure
docs.text:
• If QA defect rate spikes or blocker discovered:
  • Halt shipments, flag impacted serials.
  • Reflash affected units with previous known-good version.
  • Document issue in changelog and open ticket for root cause.

docs.title: 2. Internal Notes & Handling Rules
docs.text:
1. Eligibility Checklist
  2. Return window: 14 calendar days from delivery confirmation.
  3. Condition: device powers on, no screen/body damage, all accessories present.
  4. Software: no new accounts locked in; OEM seal/IMEI must match shipping log.
  5. Fee Collection

  7. Customer Feedback Loop

docs.text:
Last updated: 2026-02-23

Purpose: Deliver a repeatable, <60 minute prep/reset process for Motorola XT2513v units with consistent QA documentation.

docs.title: 0. Overview
docs.text:
• Prep time target: ≤60 minutes per unit (new or return). Track deltas in QA log.
  • Primary owner: Device Prep Specialist. Escalate blockers >15 minutes to Ops Lead.
  • Dependencies: Automation Engineer (scripts & tooling), Support Lead (test accounts), Ops Analyst (tracker updates).

Automation candidates (returns): script to reset + flash golden image, auto-generate condition photo log, automated health report via adb shell dumpsys summary.

docs.title: 4. QA Checkpoints
docs.text:
1. Checkpoint A (Post-Step 3 or R3): Device boots, Wi-Fi connected, OTA status logged.
  2. Checkpoint B (Post-Step 6 or R4): Workspace template hash matches manifest; automation script output archived.
  3. Checkpoint C (Post-Step 8 or R8): openclaw status OK, messaging handshake screenshot saved, audio test recorded if issue.
  4. Checkpoint D (Final): QA log entry completed, packaging photo taken, tracker updated, shipping label queued.

Each checkpoint requires initials + timestamp in QA log. Deviations → create Issue-YYYYMMDD-<serial> entry referencing mitigation.

docs.title: OpenClaw Phone Concierge Call Playbook
docs.text: Tone: warm, confident, action-first. The goal is to leave the customer feeling guided, informed, and ready to use their OpenClaw Phone daily.

docs.title: 1. Call Agenda (30 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Welcome & Goals (3 min)
  2. Confirm preferred pronouns, contact channel, and today’s objective.
  3. Reiterate the promise: "We’ll leave today with Wi-Fi connected, OpenClaw authenticated, messaging linked, and a successful first request."
  4. Hardware & Connectivity Check (5 min)
  5. Power, charging status, and Wi-Fi join.
  6. OpenClaw App Setup (12 min)
  7. Permissions, API key entry, base preferences, safety reminders.
  8. Messaging Link & First Test (7 min)
  9. Telegram/Signal/WhatsApp relay, send scripted test, confirm bot response.
  10. Wrap, Resources, Next Steps (3 min)
  11. Recap, restock reminder, support channels, follow-up commitments.

docs.title: 2. Concierge Checklist
docs.text:
Use this live during the call. Mark items ✅ / ⚠️ / ❌.

Phase Item Notes Welcome Confirm customer info (name, email, shipping address) Verify support channel for follow-ups (email, Telegram handle) Hardware Phone powered on & >50% battery or charging Wi-Fi credentials ready Connectivity Wi-Fi connected (speed test or webpage load) OpenClaw App Signed into OpenClaw setup wizard Permissions accepted (notifications, mic, camera if needed) API API key provider selected (OpenAI, Anthropic, other) API key entered & verified (status message) Preferences Timezone reflects customer location Notification style & quiet hours set Messaging Primary messaging relay linked (Telegram/Signal/WhatsApp) Bot added/approved and online status confirmed Test Scripted first message sent Successful AI response received within 30s Wrap Customer confirms they know how to ask for help Restock reminder delivered Follow-up email + channels promised

docs.text:
Collect and log in the concierge CRM note immediately after the call.

  1. Customer Profile: Full name, preferred name, company, time zone.
  2. Contact Paths: Email, primary chat handle, backup phone number if available.
  3. Device Details: Serial/asset tag, ship date, current OS build.
  4. Wi-Fi Context: Network name, any firewall/proxy notes, location (home/office).
  5. AI Provider: Which LLM account is used, confirmation that billing is active, API usage limits discussed.
  6. Messaging Channels: Which relays are live, which are deferred, who else needs access (assistants, family, etc.).
  7. Use Cases Identified: Top 2-3 daily workflows they mentioned.
  8. Open Questions / Follow-Ups: Feature requests, upcoming travel, compliance needs.

docs.text: Purpose: capture every customer signal, turn it into structured insight, and close the loop quickly. Tone: reassuring, proactive, action-driven.

docs.text:

  2. Tag consistently so patterns surface.
  3. Assign to the owner who can fix it fastest (Support, Ops, Engineering, Product, CX).

docs.title: 2. Capture Guidelines
docs.text:

  • Async Channels: Enable auto-forward to support@openclaw.com + log entries in HelpDesk within 1 hour.
  • Diagnostics: When customers send logs, attach them to the case immediately.
  • Positive Feedback: Capture quotes too—tag as "Delight" for marketing use.

Minimum data per entry: customer name, time stamp, channel, summary, impact level (P0 critical → P3 minor).

docs.title: 3. Tagging Framework
docs.text:
Use one primary tag + optional secondary tags.

Category Tag Description Reliability NoResponse, WiFi, RelayDelay, Battery, Notifications Anything affecting basic service availability Setup APIKey, TelegramRelay, Permissions, OnboardingGap Obstructions during initial 10-min setup Experience Delight, Confusion, FeatureRequest Sentiment or qualitative feedback Hardware Accessory, Restock, Damage Physical components or replacements Ops Billing, Shipping, Scheduling Process-related issues

  2. Ops handles Billing, Shipping, Restock, Accessory.
  3. Engineering handles persistent product bugs (auto-escalate when same tag appears 3+ times in a week).
  4. Product owns FeatureRequest and OnboardingGap themes; they respond with roadmap notes.
  5. CX Lead keeps ownership of Delight to repurpose quotes/testimonials.

Assignments must include due date + next action in the ticket header.

docs.title: OpenClaw Phone Troubleshooting Flow
docs.text: Tone: calm, solution-oriented. Always narrate what you are doing so the customer never feels lost.

docs.title: How to Use This Flow
docs.text:
1. Confirm the customer’s current state ("What are you seeing right now?").
  2. Enter the relevant branch below.
  3. After each fix, run a test (send the standard "Hey OpenClaw…" message) before closing.
  4. Log the outcome and tag the scenario in the feedback tracker.

docs.title: Branch A: No Response from Assistant
docs.text:
1. Check Basics
  2. Ask: “Is the phone showing Wi-Fi bars and notifications?”
  3. Toggle Airplane Mode on/off.
  4. Verify App Status
  5. Open OpenClaw app → ensure session is active.
  6. Force-quit and relaunch if frozen (swipe up, reopen).
  7. Quick Test
  8. Send in-app test prompt.
  9. If still no answer, continue.
  10. Server Health
  11. Check status.openclaw.com (if outage, set expectations & create incident note).
  12. Escalation
  13. Collect logs (Settings → Support → “Send diagnostics”).
  14. Tag ticket "NoResponse" and assign to engineering within 15 minutes.

docs.title: Branch B: API Key Errors
docs.text:
1. Confirm Provider
  2. Ask which model (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.) and whether billing is active.
  3. Validate Key Format
  4. Compare prefix (e.g., "sk-") with provider standards.
  5. Ensure no spaces/newlines when pasted.
  6. Re-Authenticate
  7. Open OpenClaw app → Settings → AI Provider → “Replace key”.
  8. Paste key, tap Verify.
  9. Quota/Permissions
  10. If error persists, log into provider portal, confirm usage/quota.
  11. Suggest temporary downgrade to a working key if main account locked.
  12. Escalation
  13. Capture screenshot of error message.
  14. Tag ticket "APIKey" and relay to Solutions team with provider status.

docs.title: Branch C: Telegram Relay Issues
docs.text:
1. Bot Status
  2. Ask customer to open Telegram → search @OpenClawSupport → confirm chat exists.
  3. Ensure bot is not muted or archived.
  4. Re-Link Flow
  5. In OpenClaw app, go to Messaging → Telegram → "Disconnect" then "Connect".
  6. Approve new request in Telegram within 60 seconds.
  7. Test Message
  8. Send "/ping" command. Expect "pong" plus timestamp.
  9. Network Constraints
  10. If still failing, confirm Telegram isn’t blocked by corporate Wi-Fi (test on LTE hotspot).
  11. Escalation
  12. Export Telegram debug log (Settings → Advanced → Export chat info).
  13. Tag ticket "TelegramRelay" and notify comms engineer for bot health review.

docs.title: Branch D: Wi-Fi Problems
docs.text:
1. Signal Check
  2. Ask customer to move closer to router. Note bars/strength.
  3. Credential Reset
  4. Forget network → re-enter password slowly.
  5. Verify 2.4 vs 5 GHz network; prefer 5 GHz when stable.
  6. Router Constraints
  7. Confirm MAC filtering / enterprise portal requirements.
  8. If captive portal, guide through browser login.
  9. Fallback Plan
  10. Connect to LTE hotspot or guest network to complete setup.
  11. Escalation
  12. Capture router model, firmware, and ISP info.
  13. Tag ticket "WiFi" and loop in Ops if hardware swap or mesh extender needed.

docs.title: Branch E: Telegram Notification but No Content (Relay Delay)
docs.text:
1. Check Message Queue
  2. In app: Messaging → Relay Health → view queue.
  3. Clear Cache
  4. Tap "Flush pending" then resend test message.
  5. Time Sync
  6. Ensure phone timezone matches server (Settings → General → Date & Time → Automatic).
  7. Escalation
  8. Collect relay log bundle.
  9. Tag ticket "RelayDelay".

docs.title: Branch F: General Wi-Fi + App Success but Device Idle Overnight
docs.text:
1. Confirm Sleep Settings
  2. Settings → Display → Auto-Lock set to at least 5 min (not 30 sec).
  3. Battery Saver
  4. Disable Low Power Mode during troubleshooting.
  5. Notification Permissions
  6. Ensure OpenClaw app notifications enabled with sound/badge.
  7. Escalation
  8. Capture screen recording of missed notification timeline.

docs.title: Closure Checklist
docs.text:
• ✅ Issue resolved test message logged.
  • 🕓 If unresolved, ETA communicated to customer.
  • 📝 Feedback tag selected (NoResponse / APIKey / TelegramRelay / WiFi / RelayDelay / Idle).
  • 📧 Follow-up summary sent via customer’s preferred channel.
